title: Introduction
text: times want upload new data MATOS. currently accepted data types formats : newly-deployed transmitters (CSV/XLS(X)) detection logs (CSV/VRL) receiver glider deployment metadata (CSV/XLS(X)) receiver events like temperature, tilt, etc. (CSV) glider GPS tracks (CSV) data types use designated Ocean Tracking Network templates: tag metadata receiver deployment metadata glider deployment metadata don’t one templates downloaded, can download package. example: , get uploading!
code: get_otn_template('glider') upload_file(project = 'umces boem offshore wind energy',             file = c('this_is_a_dummy_file.csv', 'so_is_this.csv'),             data_type = 'new_tags')

title: Extracting environmental data with `rvdat`
text: First, log MATOS account. Next, tell rvdat location vdat.exe executable (check rvdat documentation information ). Using matos, ’m going find VDAT files associated Mid-Bay Chesapeake Backbone array. Note things like temperature tilt logged within VRL/VDAT files, “detections” file type. ’ll download first file temporary directory.
code: matos_login() #> ! Please log in. #> ✔ Login successful! vdat_here("vdat.exe") detection_files <- list_project_files(   project = "UMCES Chesapeake Backbone, Mid-Bay",   file_type = "detections" ) #> ℹ These projects are missing metadata as they have not yet synced #> with OTN: "BTWaves Caribbean Acoustic Tagging", "CT DEEP Array #> (2022-2026)", "ERDC_Brunswick", "SBU Eco-Pod", "SBU Landscape Lab #> Array", "SBU NY Ocean Indicators", "UNH - Rainbow smelt", and "WCS #> New York Sand Tiger Shark Study"  head(detection_files) #>   project                  file_type upload_date #> 2     161 Tag Detections - .vfl file  2023-10-12 #> 4     161 Tag Detections - .vfl file  2023-09-13 #>                     file_name #> 2 VR2AR_546323_20231012_1.vrl #> 4 VR2AR_547715_20230912_1.vrl #> 5 VR2AR_547714_20230912_1.vrl #> 6 VR2AR_546476_20230912_1.vrl #> 7 VR2AR_546470_20230912_1.vrl #> 8 VR2AR_546462_20230912_1.vrl #>                                                       url #> 2 https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/11087 #> 4  https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/8003 #> 5  https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/8002 #> 6  https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/8001 #> 7  https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/8000 #> 8  https://matos.asascience.com/projectfile/download/7999 get_project_file(   url = detection_files$url[1],   out_dir = tempdir() ) #>  #> ── Downloading files ────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ✔ File(s) saved to: #>    C:\Users\darpa2\AppData\Local\Temp\Rtmpo3atQK\VR2AR_546323_20231012_1.vrl #>  #> ── Unzipping files ──────────────────────────────────────────────── #> [1] "C:\\Users\\darpa2\\AppData\\Local\\Temp\\Rtmpo3atQK\\VR2AR_546323_20231012_1.vrl"  vrl_file <- list.files(tempdir(), pattern = "vrl$", full.names = T)

code: env_import <- function(file) {   hold <- list.files(     tempdir(),     pattern = file,     full.names = T,     recursive = T   ) |>     read.csv(skip = 1)    names(hold) <- gsub("[_\\.]", "", tolower(names(hold)))    hold$devicetimeutc <- as.POSIXct(hold$devicetimeutc,     tz = "UTC",     format = "%F %T"   )    hold }  tilt <- env_import("ATTITUDE")  plot(tiltdeg ~ devicetimeutc, data = tilt, type = "l") depth <- env_import("DEPTH")  plot(depthm ~ devicetimeutc, data = depth) battery <- env_import("BATTERY")  plot(batteryvoltagev ~ devicetimeutc, data = battery) diagnostics <- env_import("DIAG")  plot(noisemeanmv ~ devicetimeutc, data = diagnostics) plot(ppmdetections ~ devicetimeutc, data = diagnostics) plot(ppmpings ~ devicetimeutc, data = diagnostics) dets <- env_import("DET")  head(dets[, ]) #>   detdesc       devicetimeutc time timeoffseth timecorrections #> 1     DET 2022-05-04 15:28:58   NA          NA              NA #> 2     DET 2022-05-04 15:39:32 River #> 147                                                Gloucester, VA #> 148                          Corrotoman River and Lynnhaven River #> 149                                                    Gloucester #> 150                                                               #> 151                                                          <NA> #>                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     abstract #> 1                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Tracking Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon in the main stem of the upper Chesapeake Bay and in the Bush River. Tracking migration and spawning patterns is done to keep in compliance with the ESA. Mitigation is performed by the U.S. Army to prevent any adverse effects to the populations. #> 2                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             The Atlantic Shark Institute partnered with Dr. Craig O'Connell from the O'Seas Conservation Foundation and Dr. Greg Skomal from MA Division of Marine Fisheries to use a variety of tagging technologies and methods to quantify the broad and fine-scale movements of white sharks, their feeding ecology and behavior, in the Montauk, NY area. This project was then expanded into a larger study area to get into greater specificity, more study elements, and with more tagged animals. #> 3                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Acoustic receivers had never been deployed in Rhode Island waters until 2019. In collaboration with the RI Department of Environmental Management, the Atlantic Shark Institute deployed three receivers in 2019 and now has 15 receivers throughout the RI and adjacent waters. 11 of those receivers surround Block Island, RI, three along the RI coat and one adjacent to Fisher’s Island, NY. \\r\\rThe goal is use this acoustic telemetry data and combine it with video obtained through Baited Remote Underwater Video Systems (BRUVS). We deploy BRUVS several times per month in the study area with the goal of characterizing and quantifying shark assemblages in Rhode Island state waters. #> 4                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 The Atlantic Shark Institute is leading this study on spinner sharks in New England and NY waters. With warming water temperatures spinner sharks have been moving further and further north and now have taken up residency in southern New England/New York waters in summer months. The ASI and partners will be studying all elements of this new addition and what effect it may have on the spinner sharks and other sharks that share these waters. #> 5                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               This project #> 6                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rapid growth of the wind energy industry on the US OCS has increased vessel traffic in offshore waters. This study considers the ecological role of large-bodied, low-tropic level marine species (i.e., basking shark, Cetorhinus maximus; ocean sunfish, Mola mola) and potential risks to the species from offshore wind (OSW) energy development. Data are gathered using a variety of technologies (acoustic tags, camera tags) and acoustic receivers are deployed by commercial fishing partners around the island of Martha's Vineyard, MA. #> 7          The mid-Atlantic continental shelf has been identified by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory as the coastal region with the greatest offshore wind resource potential in waters less than 60 m deep and therefore is very well suited for near-term offshore wind energy technology. Federally endangered Atlantic Sturgeon (Acipenser oxyrinchus oxyrinchus) and the commercially important Winter Skate (Leucoraja ocellata), are two species that occur in the Delaware Wind Energy Area (WEA), although there is little information on their patterns of residency and habitat. Acoustic receivers were deployed around the perimeter of the DE WEA in February 2017 to monitor the seasonal occupancy and movement of telemetered individuals. In April 2017, VEMCO acoustic transmitters were implanted in 50 Atlantic Sturgeon, and 50 Winter Skate in the Delaware coastal ocean. In addition, the receivers record the presence of species tagged with compatible transmitters identified through the ACT network. #> 8              Sandbridge Shoal is a borrow area off of Virginia that is used by multiple stakeholders to rebuild beaches. This area has also been identified as an Essential Fish Habitat (EFH) for many species, including 8 sharks characterized as Highly Migratory Species (HMS). As information about the use of the borrow area by migratory sharks is scarce, and dredging activities are expected to continue during the next few years, research efforts to improve the comprehension of the ecology of these large predators will increase our understanding of the potential effects of dredging and contribute to the eventual implementation of adapted mitigation measures. Similar research is also conducted in a similar shoal (Hens and Chickens Shoal in Delaware) where dredging activities are not conducted. A total of 15 VR2AR VEMCO receivers have been deployed to cover Sandridge Shoal and at least 25 acoustic transmitters are aimed to be deployed on individuals of various shark species in 2022 and 2023. Current funding and maintenance is housed under the NCDMF Multi-species Tagging Program. #> 55                                      The North Carolina Division of Marine Fisheries (NCDMF) in partnership with the National Marine Fisheries Service conducted a study to determine which river basins are used by American shad (Alosa sapidissima) during spawning runs in the Albemarle Sound. American shad were captured in the Albemarle Sound, tagged with sonic transmitters, and their spawning migrations were tracked using an array of acoustic receivers. Of the 62 fish which made detectable migrations during the six years of the study, 55 ascended the Chowan River while only five ascended the Roanoke River. These results indicate the Albemarle Sound stock of American shad prefer the spawning grounds in the Chowan and its tributaries, the Blackwater, Nottoway, and Meherrin rivers over those in the Roanoke River. This project contains only tagging data for American Shad tagged in this study. Seasonal migrations of three contingents (river, harbor, and ocean contingents) were investigated using both manual tracking (three seasonal campaigns) and remote data-logging receiver arrays over a 18-month period (May 2010-December 2011). #> 133                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Track a representative group of 100 Potomac River striped bass over a multi-year period within the Potomac River and across major regions and tributaries of the Chesapeake and the Atlantic Coast. #> 134                      Hudson River striped bass show highly variable migration patterns, as seen through tagging studies and otolith microchemical analyses (Clark 1968; Secor 1999). These contingent behaviors play a dominant role in the exposure of these fish to polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) (Secor and Zlokovitz 1999). We describe a study of seasonal migrations of contaminated resident striped bass to better understand the likelihood of angler consumption of these fish. We investigated the resident contingent of Hudson River striped bass, focusing on the seasonal patterns of migration by these fish. Seasonal migrations of resident fish were measured using both manual tracking (four seasonal campaigns) and remote data-logging receiver arrays (three intercept sites) over a 12-month period (October 2004-November 2005).\\r\\rResults published in Wingate and Secor, 2007. #> 135                                                                                         To bring ecosystem considerations into the current Chesapeake Bay Program striped bass FMP will require improved understanding and benchmarks for the role of water quality and habitat in influencing striped bass production. Here, we propose to better understand the constraints on resident Chesapeake Bay striped bass production under continued and perhaps worsening conditions of thermal and hypoxic stress. A widely held, but unsubstantiated view of Chesapeake Bay striped bass is that eutrophication and related increased incidence of hypoxia during summer has reduced growth and condition, and occasionally resulted in fish kills. In this study, we will directly evaluate Coutant’s thermal niche-oxygen squeeze hypothesis in the Patuxent River estuary. A central issue in the management of Hudson River striped bass is how this population contributes to coastal fisheries. What factors influence coastal migrations? This study used existing telemetry receiver assets in the Hudson River, shelf waters, and other major Atlantic estuaries to examine the influence of sex, size, and spawning reach on these coastal migrations. #> 138                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The goal of our research is to investigate the offshore movement patterns and spawning habitat use of sheepshead. Specifically, we will be using a combination of acoustic telemetry tags and Pop-up Satellite Archival Tags (PSATs) to obtain information about the movement patterns and spawning locations of adult sheepshead. #> 139                                                                 Research is focused on confirming the existence of spawning populations of Atlantic sturgeon, identify unique aspects of spawning behavior and population demographics within NC rivers, estimate passage success rates of adults at the LD-1 fishway located within the Cape Fear River, and quantify juvenile (age-1) recruitment to establish methods to support an index of abundance.  The research aims to address the following specific actions within the Carolina DPS necessary to recover Atlantic sturgeon populations which were included in the most recent NOAA Recovery Outline: 1) Improve understanding of population dynamics, population distribution, abundance, trends, and structure through research, monitoring, and modeling; 2) Continue researching fish passage designs that allow Atlantic sturgeon access to historical spawning grounds currently blocked by dams; 3) Develop standardized methods to create reliable abundance indices. #> 140                                                                                                     The Saco River Estuary support several species of migratory fishes. The goal of this study is to determine the seasonal movement and habitat use of Striped Bass and Atlantic Sturgeon in the Saco River. Using acoustic telemetry, this study  established a network of passive receivers to better understand Striped Bass seasonal movements in the Saco River, and throughout their coastal migratory range. The Gulf of Maine Distinct Population Segment of Atlantic Sturgeon are listed as threatened. Atlantic Sturgeon utilize the Saco River as a feeding ground, but move among nearby rivers. Characterizing seasonal presence and connectivity of Atlantic Sturgeon among Maine Rivers, is essential to better understand dynamics of threatened populations. Fish are internally tagged with V13 or V16 acoustic tag. Receivers are located throughout the Saco River and Saco Bay and deployed from June to November. #> 141                                                           The Coastal New England project integrates powerful technologies (acoustic telemetry, environmental DNA [eDNA], and acoustics) with traditional fisheries sampling to quantify impacts of changes in local and regional water conditions on individuals, populations, and community structure. Research includes study of the impacts of forage species and environmental conditions on Atlantic cod and common terns in both New Hampshire (Isles of Shoals) and southern Maine (Casco Bay) coastal waters. Collectively, these results demonstrate the value in novel technologies in tracking shifts in biodiversity across space and time. This project’s efforts build on the known strengths of each method (eDNA, diet analyses, active acoustics, and passive acoustics) while also exploring their integration and defining scales of appropriate use. Definitions of how each method describes marine biodiversity in both unique but also shared ways are explored. #> 142                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     <NA> #> 143     Study to determine adult Blueback Herring habitat use, movements, rates of movement, factors influencing these (environmental, biological) movements, for both upstream and downstream migration, based on fish captured and tagged near the river mouth.  A total of 32 VR2 receivers were deployed in March 2021 from the Holyoke Dam (rkm 139) to near the river mouth (rkm 5) in the main stem, with many rx sites in coves and tributaries where adult population assessment work has been ongoing by USFWS. Fish were captured in short set drift gill nets near the mouth and surgically implanted with V7 tags that were programmed for 45 days on, then off 300 days, when trigger back on, for second year return data (2022).  Tagged fish were single sutured and released often with an equal number of untagged fish from mid April through late May 2021.  A total of 155 fish were tagged and released at rates up to 12 fish in a single day. Receivers will be redeployed in March 2022 for the n=100 "2 yr" tags. #> 144                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Study focuses on the Delaware River, but the acoustic portion will also tell us about the role of Delaware Bay in shad migrations, particularly whether and to what extent the Bay serves as a staging area for shad that are continuing to migrate up the coast #> 145                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     <NA> #> 146                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Non-native Blue Catfish (Ictalurus furcatus) were intentionally introduced into the James River in the 1970’s to create a recreational fishery. This has led to increasing abundance and spatial distribution of Blue Catfish within the James River watershed and has prompted concern over the impacts of Blue Catfish on native species. The James River supports an active recreational fishery and a commercial low-frequency electrofishing fishery, with the commercial zone limited to a 100-rkm section of the tidal mainstem. The purpose of this project is to identify movement and distribution patterns and assess Blue Catfish response to LFEF in an effort to inform guidance, management decisions, and angler outreach. #> 147                                 Bowfin, Amia calva, is an evolutionarily and ecologically important species native to much of eastern North America. It is a large bodied (to 700+ mm TL) generalist apex predator in many river systems. Relatively little is known about the spatial ecology of Bowfin, with only a single study published using acoustic telemetry to determine habitat use  (from Lake Ontario; Midwood et al. 2018). Northern Snakehead, native to eastern Asia, is an established, invasive species in tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay in Maryland and Virginia. It is morphologically and ecologically similar to Bowfin. Beyond its occurrence in the tributaries, little is known of aspects of its ecology in these rivers. This study will employ acoustic telemetry to fill in these data gaps so that habitat use, movement patterns, temperature selectivity, and environmental responses of bowfin and snakehead can be assessed and compared in a tidal freshwater habitat in the mid-Atlantic region. #> 148                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Spotted Seatrout (also known as Speckled Trout) is the focus of an important recreational fishery in the southeastern United States. Management of speckled trout has also been marred by cold-stun events which can kill a significant portion of the stock and have detrimental localized effects. Virginia is the northern extent of speckled trout populations and is the most likely portion of its range to experience cold-stun events. The primary objective of this project was to use acoustic telemetry fitted with internal temperature loggers to better understand how speckled trout react to declining water temperatures and begin to assess what proportion of the population is subject to cold stun events. #> 149                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The primary research goal of this reporting period was to acoustically tag subadult sturgeons. A second goal was to monitor and maintain acoustic receiver array in the York and Rappahannock river systems. Both of these goals relate directly to two project objectives: Assess Critical Nursery Habitats and Assess Degree of Dependence of James River and York Atlantic Sturgeon on Chesapeake Bay Habitats. \\r\\rMaintenance of 2 receivers has continued, but the major array has been pulled since 2020. #> 150                                                                                           With changing climate conditions, stock health concerns, and increasing fishing pressure on many different species in Virginia’s waters, The VMRC has begun an effort to increase our understanding of the movement patterns of particularly valuable species both in the Chesapeake Bay and beyond. The initial goal of this project is to acoustically tag and monitor adult cobia and striped bass, with the potential to move into more data-poor species, such as red and black drum. This project was made possible by a grant from the Office of the Virginia Secretary of Natural and Historic Resources and was initiated as a complement to the work being done to maintain an acoustic array backbone throughout the Chesapeake Bay alongside the NOAA Chesapeake Bay Office, Maryland Department of Natural Resources, University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science, and the Smithsonian Environmental Research Center. #> 151                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     <NA>  if (FALSE) { # List your projects (which may contain some for which you do not have read access): list_projects("mine", read_access = F) }

title: Upload files to MATOS — upload_file
text: upload_file takes project name number, file want upload, type file want upload (defaulting VRL transmitter detections).
code: If data_type is "new_tags", "receivers", or "glider", only CSV and XLS/XLSX files are accepted; if "detections", only VRL and CSV files are accepted; if "events" or "gps", only CSV is accepted.  Multiple files can be uploaded at once, but they must all be the same data type and posted to the same project.

title: Upload files to MATOS — upload_file
code: if (FALSE) { # Newly tagged fish, the default upload_file(87, "your_tagged_fish.xls") upload_file(87, "your_tagged_fish.xls", "new_tags")  # Transmitter detections upload_file(   "umces boem offshore wind energy",   "c:/wherever/your_CSV_detections.csv",   "detections" ) upload_file(   "umces boem offshore wind energy",   "c:/wherever/your_VRL_detections.vrl",   "detections" )  # Receiver metadata upload_file(   "umces boem offshore wind energy",   "your_receiver_metadata.xlsx", "receivers" ) }
